Problem:
Consider a system governed by the complex function \\( z(t) = e^{it} \\) representing a circular motion in the complex plane. We then examine the impact of the transformation \\( g(z) = z^2 \\) applied to this system.

If at a certain time \\( t_1 = \frac{\pi}{2} \\), an intervention \\( h(z) = e^{-i\pi}z \\) is applied, will this affect the state at a later time \\( t = \pi \\) compared to just evolving under \\( z(t) = e^{it} \\) and not considering \\( g(z) \\)?
Explanation: The intervention with \\( h(z) \\) effectively introduces a phase shift which, combined with the initial application of \\( g(z) \\), alters the periodic trajectory differently compared to only evolving under \\( z(t) = e^{it} \\). This leads to a change in both the phase and position at \\( t = \pi \\).
